characters: THE HANGMAN REACHES FOR THE LEVER AGAIN, BUT JUST AS HE
-- THE GANG RIDES THROUGH A FIELD
-- A GROUP OF BOYS SWARM AROUND JESSE,
BUT WE HEAR A LOW WHISTLE AND
-- PINKERTON IN THE BOARD ROOM WITH HIS MAP,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Rangers plunge into thick woods. Branches slap at the but the sound of gunfire keeps them going. Captain Malcol is still in the lead, flanked by two young men who are obviously brothers. The big, handsome one is COLE YOUNGER the skinny one with the lopsided hair is BOB YOUNGER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They break through the other side of the woods, emerging behind a rickety set of fence-post fortifications. Instan GUNFIRE tears apart the trees around them. The Captain's horse goes down, and the Younger brothers dive and roll t hide beneath the palisade. The Captain, still alive, has fallen beyond the wooden shield. Cole scrambles through the savage rifle fire, gra Captain Malcolm, and hauls him behind the fortification.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bellowing) Fall back into the woods! Out of your saddles before you're shot out of 'em!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Rangers leap from their saddles as a new sound starts -- a dull roar that grows and approaches and BBRRRRAPPPPP as, unbelievably, trees EXPLODE INTO SPLINTERS and horses and men go down in a heap!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gatling! They've got a Gatling!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dammit, this stopped being fun about two years ago!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some men are crawling to the fortifications, others are staying in the woods. The Captain pokes his head up to ta a look. With him WE SEE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the top of which, about a hundred fifty yards off, is three man Gatling crew. Squads of Union soldiers are beginning to make their way down the hillside. And just t their right is an EIGHT INCH CANNON with a burning fuse -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOOM! And with a whistle the cannonball TEARS THROUGH the forest and EXPLODES just behind the Rangers. Some of the are screaming from injury and panic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cole! Bob! You boys okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, take more than a cannon to kill the Younger brothers, sir!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think the cannon's doing a pretty good job, Cole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A full-blooded Indian, COMANCHE TOM, crawls up next to th

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some Indian tracker you turned out to be, Tom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You pay me to find you Bluecoats. There they are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANOTHER ROUND from the Gatling chews up the trees and fencing, driving their heads down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're using the Gatling and the cannon to cover their advance. We're pinned unless we take them out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cole peers through the rails.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those gunners are too far away...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get me the James boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want Jesse?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not Jesse, the one who can shoot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Comanche Tom rolls back to the edge of the woods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Among the squatting men a single one STANDS UP. FRANK JAM is tall with a dark, thoughtful face. He looks sadder tha his 23 years should allow.  His hand is wrapped around a longbarrel Enfield 30.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The long rider behind him turns around. He's JESSE JAMES, 20. He's too damn good-looking and he's got your best friend's eyes. There's a coiled energy to him, and right he seems more angry than afraid. Next to him is WEB MIMMS 15, who is terrified and trying not to show it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch Web.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't need watchin'!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Web, I bring you back dead and your sister'll kill me. Now shut up and lie there. (then) Careful, Frank. And make sure Bob and Cole are okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loose shots spitting up dirt and wood chips everywhere. Frank crawls up, nods to the Youngers, peers through the stacked wood. Another EXPLOSION from the cannon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cannon or Gatling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both would be nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soon as I hit one, the other'll know and beat us up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cannon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank raises his head just high enough to poke the Enfiel over the stacked fenceposts. Everyone else is flinching f the suppressing fire. Frank is perfectly still. Squinting aiming, perfectly centered ... BANG.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the Captain of the six man crew SNAPS BACK and hits th ground dead. Before the others can react, two more grab their throats and drop. The remaining soldiers bolt from cannon. But the Gatling crew swings the gun around and the barrel BLAZE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank and the others hit the dirt as the Gatling shreds t fenceposts, fells trees, churns the ground, stitching a p of destruction across the bulwarks and into the woods whe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Gatling rounds are everywhere. Rangers jerk as the Gatling tears them apart. Jesse grabs Web to his chest an swings around, shielding the boy with his own body. When fire pauses for a moment. Jesse looks down -- he's covere in blood. He lets Web fall away. Blood bubbles up from wh the boy's chest used to be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell no...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesse's trying to stop the blood with his bare hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, Jesse. (crying) I never even got to be with a girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Web dies. Jesse sighs. He's seen too much death to cry anymore. He stands up, pivots, and strides for the fencepost barrier. Rifle fire is zipping through the air all around him, but keeps walking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank, the Younger brothers, Comanche Tom and the Captain are all still there. Captain Malcolm peers through the wa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're getting closer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesse arrives, slaps Cole's shoulder. Cole grins grimly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Bout time you got here, buddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every time I put my head up to hit that Gatling, they try to shoot it off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So we got a plan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My plan of lying here pissing myself seems to be working mighty fine, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can hit those boys from here. We just need a distraction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) A distraction? Well, why the hell didn't you just say so?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesse sprints back into the woods. Cole, Bob, and Frank exchange looks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never a good thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This ought to be interesting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANOTHER ROAR from the Gatling pushes their heads down, bu as that sound fades, another blends in, growing louder an louder, the SOUND OF HOOFBEATS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men at the fortification, turning to face the woods, their faces stunned as JESSE JAMES ON HORSEBACK AT FULL GALLOP EXPLODES from the woods, heading straight at his o men and at the last second LEAPS OVER THE BARRIER, and as does Jesse leans back in the saddle to let the wind strip off his longrider coat, revealing for the first time his GUNS -- two Colts at the hip, a crossed bandolier on his chest with two cross-holstered Colts at the shoulders, an two Colts in the small of his back. And for that one second as Jesse and the horse are in mid-air and the longrider coat trails behind him like leather wings and his guns gleam blue in the sunlight, Je James is the Angel of Death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The horse hits the ground running. The Union troops are i shock as Jesse draws both his hip Colts and starts firing

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, ya Yankee bastards!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His GUNS BLAZING, Jesse rides straight at the Bluecoats. Five, six are down before they can even react. They start firing back, but they can't draw a bead. Two more are dow Jesse's making every bullet count.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Gatling gun as the crew swings it around and FIRES, hundred of rounds tearing straight at Jesse

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesse who incredibly cuts the horse hard left using just his knees, still shooting as the Gatling volley goes wide actually killing two of the Union soldiers behind Jesse. But then the arc of fire takes Jesse's horse in the rump. The horse falls, but Jesse dives off, still firing, killi another two soldiers. Then he hits the ground, rolls, and up and running, dropping the spent Colts and drawing the shoulder guns in one smooth motion, never interrupting hi shooting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank sees the Gatling swing away from him. He stands and

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- BANG as the Gatling triggerman drops, BANG as the ammo-feeder goes down, and BANG as the third man falls before the echo of the first shot clears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cole is the first one on his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WAAAHHHHOOOO!! We're coming Jesse!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charge!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a ragged cheer the RANGERS ERUPT FROM THE FOREST, so actually on horseback, firing at the exposed Union troops

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soldiers are swarming Jesse, but he's moving, turning, an untouchable blur in the chaos. As he drops two more empty Colts and reaches for the last two at his back, a SOLDIER just an arm's length away BRINGS UP A RIFLE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you do not!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesse grabs the rifle barrel and drives the butt straight back into the soldier's nose. The Union boy falls, releas the gun. Jesse swings the rifle in a smooth arc, bashing another soldier in the jaw, and then spins it effortlessl into his opposite hand and FIRES it point blank into anot Union soldier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Rangers PLOWING INTO the Union soldiers. Rattled, the Union troops are beginning to break and fall back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesse as another nearby soldier draws a revolver. Jesse snags his hand, twists it, wrapping the man's arm backwar around Jesse's waist. With the other man still gripping t weapon, Jesse FANS THE HAMMER as he turns, shooting six m Union soldiers as they try to rush him. With a final yank Jesse pulls the Colt from the man and crashes it down on skull.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: the Union soldiers in full retreat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The few remaining Bluecoats break and run as Jesse reache the Gatling. Suddenly a FIGURE LEAPS UP from behind the Gatling and FIRES his rifle. A bloody streak tears Jesse' cheek and he stumbles onto his back. With a cry, the figu jumps forward and buries his bayonet in Jesse's chest! Jesse gasps, then, puzzled, looks down. The bayonet has lodged right in the "X" of the ammo belts on his chest, stopped by the bullets and leather. Jesse kicks. As the Union soldier is knocked back, Jesse smoothly snap-kicks his feet and draws both remaining Colts. He pulls up shor It's a fifteen year old boy, Web Mimms in a blue uniform. There's a deadly pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ain't even been with a girl, have you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy shakes his head. Jesse waves him off with the gun

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Git.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy scurries off. Jesse turns and lopes down the hill Instantly he's surrounded by cheering Missouri Rangers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Rangers move past Jesse. Jesse suddenly realizes Fran is there. They fall into step together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Distracting enough for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pff. They hardly even noticed you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you're saying I could have done more to attract their attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mm-hmm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Such as?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could have worn one of those big, floppy woman's Easter Sunday hats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That would have made an impression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I figure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See, that's your problem, Frank. By the time you finish figuring out stuff, I'm already finished doing it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Jesse, your problem is you're always doing stuff before I'm finished figuring it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cole, Bob, and Comanche Tom RIDE UP on their recovered horses. Cole jumps down and picks up Jesse in a bear hug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait'll we get back to Missouri, start telling those gals about how little Jesse James charged the whole Union Army by himself!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ride like a Comanche.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can ride like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said like a Comanche, not this Comanche.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cole mounts up, reaches down a hand to Jesse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ride with me, cousin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could use the walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suit yourself. We'll have some horses waiting for you at the road. (then) Let's ride, Rangers!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cole slaps leather and the Rangers canter off. As they disappear we hear:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (low) Now, I would just sound stupid saying something like that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesse and Frank watch them go, then start walking again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (finally) Web's dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I reckoned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell of a war.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure it seemed like a good idea at the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The James brothers, the Youngers, and the other Rangers ride down a dirt road toward a ragtag column of Confedera soldiers. The grey uniforms are ghostlike in the twilight The men are obviously broken, dispirited. The column stretches down the road and around a bend as far as the e can see. Jesse and the other Rangers ride into the midst of the Confederates who part and flow around the horsemen like a slow-moving river. For a moment, nobody speaks while the whole eerie procession glides past.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where you boys going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's Yankees back there. Lot's of 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One grizzled Confederate VETERAN, his arm in a bloody sling, looks up at Jesse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: War's over, son. General Lee surrendered yesterday at Appomattox.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The soldiers move on. The Rangers stare into the middle distance of despair. Cole rubs his hands across his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, somebody better go tell THE DAMN YANKEES!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do we do now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesse seems to be the only one with a clear head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Home. We go home. We ride like hell to get there, and we kill anything or anyone that comes between us and our homes. And when we get there we stay there and God help any fool who tries to get me to leave my farm again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause) Best damn plan I heard all war.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesse jerks his reins, and the last remaining survivors o the Missouri Rangers trot off into the sunset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Jesse, Frank, the Youngers and Comanche Tom riding har down country roads, past burned out farms.

dialogues.speaker: THE RIDERS
dialogues.text: Are struggling through a downpour in a pitch black night, one of the horses slipping, going down.

dialogues.speaker: BLAZING SUN
dialogues.text: On a dusty road, the Youngers sharing a horse now, everybody just trying to keep moving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesse, Frank, Cole, Bob, and Comanche Tom are looking dow on the frontier town of Liberty, Missouri.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Liberty Missoura!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All this time in the saddle... We get to the farm, I'm going to shoot this damn horse just on principle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never thought that pissant town would look so pretty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anywhere nobody's shooting at me is pretty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Home, boys. Back to our farms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Planting corn. Harvesting corn. Year after year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corn gonna shoot at me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I love it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They start to ride down into town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom, why don't you stop at our spread before you head on out to the reservation? Figure we might have some work for you, if you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmm. Go back to the reservation and get drunk in a dirt shack, or work for you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm thinking...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cole throws a playful punch at Comanche Tom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gang is riding into the main stretch of town. They're grinning, happy to be home, until --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got problems.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOZENS OF UNION SOLDIERS are walking along the boardwalk, lingering near the saloon, all suddenly staring at the riders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Must be a garrison in town. We're in occupied territory, boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cole is returning stares.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hands off your hip, Cole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not scared, are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pick your fights, cousin. You taught me that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It gets worse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There in the center of town, is a brand new scaffold. Thr bodies, fresh ones, are hanging from the nooses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus mercy, that's Charlie Higgins, Dave Laller ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Will Perry ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They rode with Quantrill's Rangers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The riders stop at the scaffold, take off their hats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like Web Mimms wasn't the only casualty this town's got.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We better go to Doc's, see what's going on here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm cutting them down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cole starts to dismount. Jesse grabs his arm. The Union Soldiers have started to form a crowd

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is wrong with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (low) In case we have to kill these sonofabitches, I don't want them to see us coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cole thinks, nods. They ride away from the scaffold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cole, I want to get to the farm, make sure Little Jim and the girls are okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop by our spread after that, tell our Ma we're all right. We'll go to Doc Mimms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Youngers and Comanche Tom split off, start to trot aw

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I may just go on to the reservation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom, I'm this close to coming with you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesse and Frank ride toward a handsome white two-story frame house that stands in a grove of elm trees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They dismount and walk up to the porch. A FARM HAND in a cowboy hat is nailing a rail onto the porch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scuse me, we're here for the Doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The farm hand turns and pulls off his hat -- her hat. She a chestnut-haired beauty in her late teens, ZERELDA MIMMS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesse! Frank!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hugs both of them enthusiastically. Jesse is obviousl immediately smitten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zerelda? Little Zee Mimms?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were little Jesse James when you left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you got big!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zee arches an eyebrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, you aged --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zee arches both eyebrows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, I mean, in a good way you got big and older.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zee tilts her head. Jesse's mouth moves, but nothing come out, until

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank, don't you have something to say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're doing just fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pulling it together) Zee, we got to talk to you and your father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOC MIMMS, a grey-haired man wearing rimless spectacles, steps out of the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank, Jesse. (looking) Where's Web?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A LONG SHOT of the Mimms house. We can see, but not hear, Jesse talking. A beat, then we hear Zee CRY OUT.  Doc Mim staggers, SLUMPS DOWN in the door frame. Jesse and Frank rush to help him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is comfortable and elegant in a simple way. Doc Mimms is slumped in a big chair. Zee, her eyes red, is pushing a glass of sherry into his hands. Jesse and Frank sit across from him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- rode right into them, screaming like a banshee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My little Web did that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pff. He jumped his horse clear over our heads, killed a dozen Union soldiers before they knew what hit them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesse looks at Frank, urging him on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whyyyy... he took down the Gatling gun and the cannon all by himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saved all our lives, Doc. None of the Liberty boys would have come home if not for Web Mimms, Doc. God's honest truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc is fighting back tears, but proud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Web died fighting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Died a hero.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) But still died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If there's anything we can do for you, Dr. Mimms. We want to help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Start thinking about yourselves. You, the Youngers, Clell Miller, all of you. Don't end up like Charlie. They found out Charlie rode with Quantrill's Raiders. They arrested him, tried him by military tribunal and hanged him this morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought there was general amnesty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For soldiers, yes. But if you rode in one of the partisan bands, they'll hang you for treason. And you boys are in more danger, because you've got a farm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesse and Frank don't understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy, don't start with this again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zerelda, it's no coincidence. The railroad men come through, offering to buy up land. Nobody sells. Then they start hanging men who own farms for treason?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're saying the railroad's got the Army doing it's dirty work?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rich men in Washington, don't matter if they wear a tie or a uniform, they're all the same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All we thought about was coming home. I swore I'd kill anybody who tried to get me off my farm again. If I have to go to war with the railroad to stay, fine by me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think about this. If we just come up with a story and stick to it, we should be all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of story are they going to believe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmm. You were in the Confederate Army with General Hood's Texas Army until... say Sharpsburg, then you were reassigned to General Jeb Stuart's cavalry until you surrendered in Tennessee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause. The men stare at Zee. Up goes the eyebrow again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That just might work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe, maybe...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now go on to see your Ma. She'll be glad to see her sons alive. (choking) And for her sake, stay that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Frank and Jesse mount up. Zee is at the door seein them off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll be back on Saturday with Cole and Bob, give you a hand with the repairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. For everything. Especially that story you told my father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesse is about to object, but Zee raises a hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to go cry now, so I don't have time for your lies. But I'll see you Saturday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zee kisses her fingertips and extends them to the boys, then disappears into the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank shaking his head as they ride away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That Zerelda turned into a hell of a woman, eh --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WIDEN TO REVEAL Jesse's not next to him. Frank turns. Jesse's still staring at the door.  Frank rides back, tak Jesse's horse by the reins.  As Frank turns Jesse's horse and leads it away, Jesse's head keeps pivoting, fixed on door. After a moment, Jesse turns to look forward, taking his reins. The brothers ride away slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Big and older"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can shut up now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are a charmer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I swear I'll shoot you in your sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next time try "fat and haggard."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesse pulls down his hat and groans into it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesse and Frank ride up. Out of the farmhouse bursts MA JAMES, a big, rugged frontier woman who is absolutely hysterical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My boys! My boys!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hauls Jesse and Frank clean out of their saddles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My boys are alive!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (strangling) Not if you don't ease up a bit, Ma...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at both at arm's length.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you kill Yankees?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fair number, Ma.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say your prayers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every night, Ma.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. Now get inside and wash up for dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesse and Frank enter, surprised to find Cole, Bob, Comanche Tom, and a gawky 15 year old JIM YOUNGER all eat at their kitchen table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well look at Jimmy Younger. You're all grown up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mouth full) Mmmph-hmpph.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sheepishly) Your Ma wouldn't let us leave until we ate something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was two hours ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't see clean plates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men dutifully return to the meal. Jesse nods his head at Comanche Tom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quiet) Ma, I'm glad to see you being nice to our Injun friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a good Christian and he killed Yankees. Jesus told me that made him an all right boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ma WALKS OFF.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's still talking to Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What worries me is that Jesus is talking back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can hear the laughter from inside the lit house. Night falls and

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like a time-lapse film we see the surrounding trees have filled out, the stone fence is repaired, the shabby paint redone in sparkling white. Jesse and Cole, shirtless, are driving a post into a hole. Frank STEPS OUT of the house joins them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ever notice Zerelda's eyes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She got two of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think one of 'em's glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which one, right or left?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The brown one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Cole) You talk big for a man who screwed another man back in Atlanta.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank laughs as Cole raises the shovel to strike Jesse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Lord, the dance hall girl at Bunty's...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sadie was not a man!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She had a moustache.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was European!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, calm down. I'll agree Sadie was a woman --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesse and Frank swallow their laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- if you stop saying things about my Zee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Zee? Hmm. (quoting) "From women's eyes this doctrine I derive: they sparkle still the right Promethean fire; They are the books, the arts, the academes, that show, contain, and nourish all the world."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no idea what you just said, but it sounded real nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shakespeare. (pause) He's European.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to write that down for me so I can say it to Zee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The post finally drops straight into the hole. Jesse and Cole shrug into shirts and grab a pitcher of lemonade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for the help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After all you did on our farm? (sips, then) You miss it, don't you Jesse?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The war? What, are you crazy? (beat) There are things I miss about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was exciting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it was a whole lot of killing. Why should we miss that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because we were good at it?  Hell, we were great at it. Jesse, don't tell anyone I said this, because everybody knows I'm the toughest man in this town, but you are one terrifying sonofabitch with those guns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (regretful, but not) Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank looks at Jesse thoughtfully. Then all three notice

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A BUGGY that stops at the edge of the property. Ma STEPS OUT onto the porch next to Frank to meet: A man in a suit, ROLLIN PARKER, and three riders who dismount and flank Parker: two DETECTIVES and a big Scot with a beard and no moustache, ALAN PINKERTON. Pinkerton wearing a suit and a gun in a high waistband. All four advance to the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Howdy, folks. How are you this afternoon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Howdy"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easterners.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're just fine, thank you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am Rollin H. Parker, personal emissary of Mr. Thaddeus Rains, president of the Rock Island and Pacific Railroad. These two gentlemen are Pinkerton detectives, working for Mr. Thaddeus Rains, president of the Rock Island and Pacific Railroad, and this gentleman here is the famous Alan Pinkerton, founder of the Secret Service and now working under contract to Mr. Thaddeus Rains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would that be Thaddeus Rains, president of the Rock Island and Pacific Railroad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heard of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to regain control) As you have no doubt heard from your neighbors, our railroad is moving west.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That makes sense, as east would put you underwater.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pinkerton coughs a laugh. Parker glares at him and continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... moving west, opening the frontier for folks such as yourself. Your acreage here is on the proposed right of way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parker produces a piece of paper. Ma takes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm here for your signature on this land sales contract. I'm authorized to pay you two dollars an acre.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two dollars?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right. That's the price authorized by the railroad's board, and approved by the Department of the Interior of the Government of the United States of America.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This land ain't for sale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pinkerton steps forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ma'am, I can understand how you might feel that way -- you've made a lovely home here. But it's really not up to me or you. Are you familiar with the legal concept of the Right of Eminent Domain?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I am. What about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parker is surprised. Pinkerton has become interested in these farmers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, this land is about to be condemned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm doing you folks a favor --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Said the skinner to the mule.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- with a price of two dollars an acre for this one time only offer. After today the price goes down. So if I were you, I'd just sign the contract, and I'll be on my way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank takes the contract from Ma and hands it back to Parker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good day, Mr. Parker You can tell Mr. Thaddeus Rains to put this where the sun don't shine. (to the boys) Shakespeare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parker flushes with anger. Pinkerton and his men rest the hands on their guns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think you understand. You don't have a choice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLICK CLICK and we see Jesse's drawn and cocked two Colts from out of thin air. Frank has pulled his rifle from the doorway. Parker and the detectives are furious, but Pinkerton seems no more than curious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Ma) Ma'am. You have to look in your heart and do what you know is right here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me ask the Lord.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ma bows her head for a moment. She then nods and looks up

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Lord says we can bury 'em out back in the orchard, nobody'll ever find them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody's in a vengeful smiting mood today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't we just let them go for today, Ma. We'll bury them out back next time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parker, and the detectives are stepping backward to the buggy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You people are making a serious mistake!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pinkerton himself has lingered, taking in the group.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding) Nicely played.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parker, Pinkerton and the detectives RIDE OFF. The group the James house watches them go, then Cole turns to Jesse

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where the hell did you get those guns?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dozens of men and a few women are packed into the one roo school house. Among them are Frank and Jesse. Doc Mimms i leading the meeting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I went up to the courthouse and looked at the right of way documents for the rail bed. The railroad doesn't even need our land, they're just taking the land on both sides for as far as they can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn. All that reading paid off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Floor recognizes Clell Miller.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLELL MILLER, tall and blond, steps forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're saying we don't sell, we might end up with nothing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's only if we don't stick together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing) Loni Packwood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LONI PACKWOOD, a sad, scruffy man stands up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I say this is the last straw. I came back from the war, I found my house burned down. My cows was dead. Now my wife's run off with my cousin, Jeb, that sonofabitch. (tearing up) Took my dog--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, Loni, about the railroad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I forget. (almost weeping) Took my dog...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another FARMER steps up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I signed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harlan, you can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm tired of fighting. I'm just gonna take my family and move west.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe we should hire a lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a good idea!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It would be, if the courts were on the up and up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what do we do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: the school house door as it BANGS open and Bob Younger STUMBLES IN, bleeding from a cut on his forehead, being supported by Zee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They got Cole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He collapses into a seat. The crowd surrounds him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He came to our house, Daddy. I figured you'd all want to hear this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesse and Frank are next to Bob. Zee puts a hand on Jesse shoulder. He notices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They came up, made the same offer they made you folks. Our little brother Jim tried to chase 'em off, one of those detectives hit him in the head, knocked him out. Cole lost his temper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rubbing his forehead) Oh no...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He just lost his temper a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sighing) How many of them did he kill?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They said because the detectives were working for the Department of the Interior --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Army can hang him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do we do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd stares at Jesse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You folks are going to do nothing. You're all going to go home right now. So you're going to be able to swear on a Bible that you don't know anything about what's going to happen tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesse's gaze is at once noble and terrifying. The crowd quietly begins to disperse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boys...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go home, Doc. (softly) They ain't gonna hang no more Liberty boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc Mimms nods, EXITS. Jesse walks to the other end of the school house. Bob, Frank, Clell and Loni fall in behind him. The door SWINGS OPEN again and Comanche Tom enters with Jim Younger sport six-guns way too big for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't lose him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim Younger, I told you--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's my fault they're gonna hang Cole. I want in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim, it was just a matter of time before they tried to hang somebody else to scare off the other farmers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you're too young.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Jesse) I'm the same age you were when you went off to war.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the same age Web was. No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're wasting time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zee joins them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zee, go home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zee's eyebrows go up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who else was there when they hanged the others?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men look at each other. Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You need to know how they do it. Which way they walk up. What order they do things in. And if you mess up rescuing Cole because you won't listen to a woman, then God damn you all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. Seven of us against a Union regiment and Pinkerton detectives in broad daylight in the middle of Main Street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesse smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that bad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soldiers flank the gallows, which stand at the bottom of the stairs to City Hall. A small drum corps beats a stark rhythm. Parker is watching this like a sideshow. Pinkerton is nex to him, scanning the crowd of locals which is getting lar and surlier by the minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Relax, Alan. The Army has this all in hand. And Mr. Thaddeus Rains will be very pleased with this news. Nothing like a hanging to motivate the populace to relocate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not my job to relax. I've put men facing out both ways down Main Street, so nobody can ride in shooting. I've got a sharpshooter up on the water tower just in case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pinkerton WAVES to a FIGURE in a suit atop the water towe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see it is FRANK JAMES in the suit, who WAVES BACK and then kneels and sights down his long rifle. Tucked away behind him, out of sight from the street, is a bound-and-gagged PINKERTON SNIPER in his underwear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cole, his face swollen from a beating, is marched up the stairs of the gallows toward the waiting hangman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: of the gallows, detectives and soldiers down the street o both sides, guns ready. The position is completely unassailable. Cole is at the platform. His hands are tied front of him. The noose is placed on his neck.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO
dialogues.text: The gallows. Parker leans forward in anticipation. A UNIO LIEUTENANT approaches with the black hood. Cole spits in face. The CROWD ROARS. The Lieutenant angrily motions to HANGMAN, who grabs the lever -- The drums STOP -- But the drumming doesn't. The drum corps look at each other, confused. The Army men and the Pinkertons squint in concentration. There's definitely some sort of rhythmic DRUMMING, coming closer. The CROWD, sensing something, easing back from the gallows... The drumming gets LOUDER ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REVEAL Fifty-odd CATTLE suddenly STAMPEDING from down the street, their hooves creating the drumming! REACTION SHOTS as the Pinkertons and Army men start to scatter, the cattle surging around them --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON Parker and Alan Pinkerton running for cover, Pinkerton half-turned to watch the action.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brilliant...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pinkerton suddenly spots something confusing. We FOLLOW h stare to see --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: a HORSE in the middle of the cattle, cutting through the steer, towards the gallows.

dialogues.speaker: DOES -
dialogues.text: Jesse -- masked -- appears from the side of the horse, where he's been hanging on Indian-style. He gets a leg up the horse's back and LEAPS -- SLAMMING into the Hangman, bringing him down! The cattle pass the gallows, revealing that the tight ran of the Army and Pinkertons are now spread out --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SMASH! From the nearby GENERAL STORE, the other masked rescuers CRASH through the big front window on horseback ride into the Army men, FIRING AWAY. TOTAL CHAOS! The Army men and Pinkertons fight towards th gallows. As Jesse untangles himself from the Hangman, the Union Lieutenant reaches for the lever but BANG drops as Frank opens fire. Frank starts picking off soldiers. The detectives and remaining soldiers are completely disoriented.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesse flashes a knife and the noose drops away from Cole' neck. Facing Cole, he cuts the rope on Cole's wrists -- Cole instantly draws Jesse's guns from his waist holster, spin-reverses them and SHOOTS two Union soldiers climbing the stairs behind Jesse's back.  Jesse and Cole exchange look, then Jesse steps away -- As Bob rides by he TOSSES JESSE'S GUNBELT into the air. Jesse draws both guns from the belt as it flies by, spins and starts shooting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The soldiers have totally broken ranks. One riderless hor led by Comanche Tom pulls up by the scaffold. Jesse LEAPS and Cole jumps on behind him. Jesse puts the spurs to it the horse SURGES into a gap in the crowd. Allen Pinkerton steps past the panicking troops, squarely in the path of the charging horse. He draws his gun and FIRES. The bullet PLOWS into Jesse just as the terrified horse lurches forward, TRAMPLING Pinkerton. Cole holds Jesse up and the riders take off down the street. We see Frank has disappeared from the water tower The soldiers fire at the fleeing liberators. One of the detectives runs over to the injured Alan Pinkerton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, are you all right? (shout) Somebody get a doctor!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WE SEE one window upstairs with a light on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc Mimms has just finished bandaging Jesse, who lies unconscious beneath the sheets. Zee is holding an oil lam

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's going to be fine, right Daddy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bullet came out clean, but he lost a whole lot of blood. Praying wouldn't hurt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SOUND OF HOOFBEATS APPROACHES from outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc Mimms opens the door. A UNION OFFICER and a squad of soldiers push in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening, sir, we're looking for a fugitive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fugitive? Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't know, but he was very badly wounded. We're checking all the houses in the area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zee hears her father protesting, then FOOTSTEPS on the stairs. Quickly she undresses, grabs a quilt from a chest and jumps into bed with Jesse. She pulls the quilt up to neck, completely hiding him. At that moment, the Officer barges in. Zee lets out a little gasp as if startled awake. She covers herself with the quilt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir! Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Sorry ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should hope so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Officer EXITS. Zee watches the door for a moment, the looks down fondly at Jesse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesse, are you awake?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (groggy) Mmmm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zee gently pushes his hair off his face. Then her expression changes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesse, is that your hand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nuh-huh ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesse smiles in his sleep. Zee jumps out of the bed and wraps a dressing gown around herself. Doc Mimms enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're gone. What are you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I fooled them into thinking I was alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I hope the boy pulls through. We should know in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a little smile) I think he's already feeling better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A puzzled Doc Mimms follows her out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lavishly appointed carriage rolls up to the front of th nicest hotel in town. Rollin Parker and his retinue of Pinkerton detectives scurry to the door. The DOOR OPENS. Out steps THADDEUS RAINS, wearing an elegant suit he bought in London last year and a scowl he picked up in Boston three decades ago. The scowl fits him better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Thaddeus Rains, sir, it is a pleasure to have you join us in the field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it is my pleasure to be here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NO! It is NOT my pleasure to have to leave my board room to come to this godforsaken piece of dirt to discover why in the name of all that is holy you cannot seem to evict a few simple farmers from their PATHETIC LITTLE MUDHOLES so that I may build the GREATEST railroad that this country has ever seen!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can completely understand your distress, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rains sighs. As he speaks, he checks a heavy, gold, ornat and ever-present POCKETWATCH on a GOLD CHAIN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parker, tell me what's going on so I can return as quickly as possible to Boston and my whores and cigars, not necessarily in that order.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two weeks ago, we managed to arrange to have the Army hang one of the local farmers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unfortunately not, sir. A gang of local thugs managed to rescue him from the gallows. Not only has this inspired resistance from the other farmers, the redoubtable Mr. Alan Pinkerton was seriously injured during the incident.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leaving you in charge of operations until he recovers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (puffing with pride) Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just perfect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A further impediment is that the Army garrison has been ordered to move on from Liberty. We will no longer have that particular stick with which to threaten the farmers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see the Army leaving and you see the loss of a tool. I see a power void to be filled. As we have the most power, we may move with impunity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see. I'll get together four patrols of our detectives for action tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll teach these podunks what happens when they challenge the righteousness of progress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zee is on the porch. Jesse COMES THROUGH the door, moving gingerly. Zee immediately moves to support him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shouldn't be up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been on my back two weeks. I'm sick of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're sick of my company?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! I mean, of course not. No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teasing you is completely unfair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you do to me is unfair. The teasing, I mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I shouldn't tease a hero.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody in the county knows it was you who rescued Cole. We're all so proud of you, Jesse. And not a single farm's been sold to the railroad since. You're everybody's hero.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wasn't the only one risking my neck that day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you're saying I should leave you alone and go spend time with Jimmy Younger?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unfair. You are completely unfair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look at each other warmly. Frank DRIVES UP in a carriage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ready to stop loafing around with this young lady and get back to farming?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you get in the carriage? Until Ma has you home so she can fuss over you herself, she's gonna make me miserable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc Mimms COMES OUT onto the porch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you say, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on. You're pretty much all healed up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesse and Zee exchange glances. Zee withdraws demurely in the house. Jesse straightens up and hops easily into the carriage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're looking a bit more spry now that somebody --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Frank) Shut up. (to Doc Mimms) Uh, Doc, I was wondering if, uh, this evening, I could come by?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know you're welcome any time!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (unusually awkward) Yesss, but I was thinking, I could come by, and then take Zee out. Some place near. With other folk. Near. Here. (beat) But out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bemused) It's fine by me, Jesse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, sir, I'll make sure they're always properly chaperoned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesse slooooowly turns to glare at Frank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grinning) Why, that hadn't even occurred to me, Frank. I am deeply in your debt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Army's leaving town, so Cole can stop hiding up in the woods and come back to his farm. Everybody's getting together at the Younger place for a to-do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank tips his hat, and the carriage MOVES OFF.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dozens of people are milling about happily in the lantern light of a Western party. Some are dancing to the small banjo-led band. A small knot of men are comparing war stories. Cole Younger is wandering among them, people clapping his shoulder, shaking his hand. Jesse -- formally accompanying Zee -- and Frank arrive at the edge of the light. Immediately the entire group burst into applause and crowds Jesse. Cole cuts through and bea hugs Jesse, making him wince.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's Liberty's favorite son! (quietly) I'll never forget what you did, cousin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zee, I'm pleased you came.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why thank you, Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm especially pleased you came with Jesse. (off her look) Seeing as right now there's a gaggle of girls hoping to dance with Jesse who are just going to have to settle for the many charms of Bob Younger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A group of obviously disappointed, beautiful young women. Bob runs a hand through his hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have no shame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not yet. But I'm hoping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The party starts up again, and everyone is caught up in t good times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesse SWINGING Zee into a group of dancers. They join in the Two-Step, and Jesse's as smooth as silk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesse, carrying a lantern, and Zee are walking. We can he the party still going just a little ways away. They reach tree at the hilltop with a beautiful view of the stars an the river. They sit down, their backs against the tree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I used to come to this tree when I was a kid and imagine what my life would be like when I got older.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't want to farm?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was thinking more along the lines of being a river pirate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A river pirate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arr. Hand over your jewels, Missy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank God you grew out of that. (pause) You did grow out of that, didn't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mostly. It would be an all right life, for a bachelor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You planning on being a bachelor your whole life, Jesse James?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not if I find the right girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what's this right girl like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smart. Funny. Bossy. Always makes me think she's two steps ahead of me. And big buck teeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where will you find such a girl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honestly, you'd do if only you had the buck teeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zee fakes a monstrous overbite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dreamy) Finally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two move a little closer. Eye contact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahem. "From this doctrine..." No, ah... "From women's eyes this doctrine I derive, they sparkle still like ... shiny... sparkling rocks..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sparkling rocks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little ones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this one of Frank's Shakespeare poems you're trying to quote?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were you planning on kissing me when you finished quoting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been planning on kissin' you for a very long time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They kiss. It's everything it should be.

dialogues.speaker: BOOM
dialogues.text: Jesse and Zee are startled by a flash of light and sound. They turn to look back --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The partygoers are RUNNING from the YARD to the BARN, whi is ON FIRE in several different places. As the Younger brothers and Frank get close, they see a squad of masked riders disappearing down the road. Some of the men SHOOT the riders, but the distance is too great. Jim makes a run for the BARN, but Bob grabs him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BASTARDS! Come back here and face me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get buckets!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some of the crowd starts to form a bucket line to the wel Jesse and Zee RUN UP. Frank turns to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pinkertons. It's the railroad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ma.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank and Jesse bolt for their horses, swing into the saddles and GALLOP OFF.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From a bit down the road, looking just fine. Jesse and Frank reign in as relief rushes across their faces -- AN EXPLOSION tears the house apart like a pile of matchsticks! Jesse and Frank urge their horses into a ful gallop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesse and Frank leap from their mounts, trying to get clo to the house. The flames are too strong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ma! Ma!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesse's ventured so close his coat catches fire. Frank tears it from him and stamps it out. Jesse ignores him, still pacing back and forth in front of the inferno.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ma! Please!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (weakly) Boys?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The brothers turn and nearly drop from shock. Ma is stumbling toward them, half her hair singed off, brutally BURNED.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus mercy --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They reach her just as she collapses. Jesse is cradling her, Frank with his arms around both of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Riders --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We know, Ma. Now we got to get you to Doc Mimms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take care of each other, boys. You say your prayers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesse is openly crying. Frank has tears silently streamin down his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc Mimms will --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ma's eyes turn up, and she half-smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well look at that. The Good Lord's a bit shorter than I reckoned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ma gently stops breathing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys holding Ma, framed by the roaring flames of thei home. Jesse leans his head back and lets out a HOWL OF RA AND PAIN AND HATE that goes on and on and on...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank and Jesse are staring at the smoking ruins of their lives. Other townsfolk are milling nearby, including Zee the Youngers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... We could move on. Rebuild. Make a decent life someplace else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't care.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't think you would. (turning away) I'm going to go make the coffin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make a thousand of 'em. Still won't be enough by the time I'm through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our place, Clell Miller's, Sammy Johnston, the Creeders. Will Hite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sheriff says it was a gang of drunk Kansas boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I say we ride into town and kill us some Pinkertons and railroad men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stare at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't a feud, this is war. They've got more men than we do. We kill detectives, they can replace 'em in a day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (snapping) So what do we do, General Lee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just like in the war. Harass their supply lines. We kill the railroad's men, they won't care.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But if we take their money and supplies...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a great plan, Jesse!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cole nods grudgingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll get us a few more men, and Comanche Tom'll ride with us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where do we hit first, Jesse?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll pick the first job! I mean... I know a girl down at the bank. See if she can't get a list of towns where the railroad keeps its money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perfect, Cole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's ride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Youngers mount up. Jesse walks to the ruined house, pulls a big iron trunk from the wreckage. He KICKS it ope reaches in, and pulls out his gun belts. Zee appears behi him in what remains of the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am so sorry, Jesse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank and me have to go away for a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zee considers this, puts her head in close to Jesse's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You and I, we've started... something, you know? (Jesse nods) I don't know what'll happen if you do this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me neither.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let the law --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laws don't touch men like Thaddeus Rains. Only justice does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whose justice? Yours or God's? (no answer) When will you stop?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When my name makes them cry in their sleep. When I've brought them to ashes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesse kisses her gently, turns and walks to where the Youngers are standing. Zee can barely conceal her anger a heartbreak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ESTABLISHING SHOT of a Midwestern bank on a quiet street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are two teller windows, a couple of male customers and a MOTHER and CHILD. Jesse and Cole ENTER dressed for the trail, longrider coa and spurs. Saddlebags are slung over their shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, ladies and gentlemen, but I have bad news. The railroad payroll has been stolen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BANK MANAGER steps out from behind his desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? The railroad's money is right over there in that safe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesse draws two guns, Cole produces a shotgun from his co

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That safe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank James, Bob and Jim Younger, Clell Miller, Loni Packwood, Comanche Tom and several new GANG MEMBERS wait along both sides of the street in this medium sized mid-western town. Some are standing next to their horses, some mounted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An OLD MAN with a cane is walking shakily towards the ban Frank jerks his head and Jim intercepts him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold on there, sir. Bank's closed today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wha?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bank holiday! Bank's closed!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim tries to steer the old man away. The old man starts batting at him with the cane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get off me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ow! Ow!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesse and the Bank Manager are having a staredown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is outrageous. Who are you people?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The James Gang.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (annoyed) The James-Younger Gang.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't let it happen again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old man is still smacking Jim with the cane. Bob crosses to help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, it's a bank holiday --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SMACK SMACK and now the old man's laying the cane on both Bob and Jim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ow!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ow ow!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank hangs his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cole turns to the Woman and Child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ma'am, kindly cover that child's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want her to see me shoot this man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The woman covers the child's eyes. Cole raises the shotgu Jesse half covers his eyes and turns his head. The Manage swallows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Comanche Tom walks over to where the old man is still SMACKING Jim and Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know it ain't no durned bank holiday!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why can't I go in there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On account of we're robbing it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Why didn't you just say so?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a secret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. I'll just wait here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd appreciate that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old man settles against the wall. Comanche Tom moves back to his horse. Bob and Jim walk off, glaring at the o man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lean, middle-aged SHERRIFF is walking by his window. Hi DEPUTY is whittling at the desk. The Sherriff pulls up sh

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old Man Tucker is just standing quiet outside the bank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When have you ever known Old Man Tucker not to be yelling at everybody?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes in the group of riders, reaches for his rifle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesse and Cole RUN FROM the bank with full saddlebags. Everybody MOUNTS UP and starts riding down main street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd it go in there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. How'd it go out here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're gonna have to talk...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BANG! The gang flinches as a chunk of wood splinters from post. They turn to see the Sherriff running out in front them, raising his rifle -- The entire Gang draws their guns. Jesse raises a hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, you can do this the smart way, or the stupid way. Only one way ends with you still breathin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Sherriff takes in the Gang's firepower. He lowers the rifle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the Gang) Just 'cause we're robbing a bank, no reason not to be civil about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Gang turns and RIDES OFF hard. The DEPUTY walks up to the Sherriff a beat later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where the hell were you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had you covered. (beat) From back there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bonfire burns in the middle of a rough camp in the wood The Gang members are sitting around, relaxing and drinkin coffee. All eyes are on Jesse and Cole as they finish counting the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got seven thousand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got three.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten thousand dollars! That's almost a thousand apiece!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men HOOT AND HOLLER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My luck is changing at last!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cole holds up a pile of papers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These are deeds and mortgages of farms the bank was holding for the railroad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better pass them over here before something happens to 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cole goes to hand the papers to Bob and "accidentally" drops them in the fire. The men CHEER again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, settle down. All this money ain't ours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, no, Jesse, it was the bank's. That's why we had to go to all that trouble of stealing it. (to Frank) You explain it to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We oughta take some of this, give it to our neighbors in Liberty. Lot of people hurting up there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: None of them risked their necks for this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, let's think about this. We create some good will with the folks hereabouts, make it easier to dodge the law.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See, Frank's being smart about this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just because he reads all those books and knows all those big words doesn't make him smart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uhh, yeah it does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You stay out of this, Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think Jesse's got a good idea --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You stay out of this too, Jim. (to Jesse) Who put you in charge of this gang, anyway, Jesse? I did mighty fine leading us during the War.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I planned getting you off the hangman's deck --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that's why you both lead the gang. Two of you went into that bank together, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesse and Cole nod, still watching each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two heads are better than one. All Jesse was doing was making a suggestion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesse nods, his face giving nothing up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So we're waiting to hear what you think of the suggestion. As the other leader of the gang.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cole considers this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I reckon it's the smart thing to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other Gang members grumble. Cole whirls on them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! We decide something, that's it! We're in this for the long haul, and this idea of me and Jesse's will help give us more places to hide out without worrying about some farmer with a shotgun sneakin' up on us in our sleep. We've got to think --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Strategically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Exactly. Because this is a war.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This ain't no war.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
