dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was for my Ma. Now this is for everybody else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's too important, James.  They'll set the army on you. You and your wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesse stares at Rains, Rains stares back, the tension building...Jesse's about to shoot...and says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is a nice watch you got there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rains looks down at the fob, back up. The tension isn't broken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tell you what, I'll buy that watch from you, for the fair market price approved by the Department of the Interior: one dollar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rains hesitates. Jesse thumbs the hammer back

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I were you, I'd sell. After this, the price goes...down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rains tosses the Watch to Jesse as Jesse simultaneously FLIPS Rains a dollar coin with his free hand. Jesse holds the Watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now every time you go to look at this watch and it's not there, you'll remember: You can be stopped. Pass that down to your son, instead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesse thumbs the hammer forwards, lowers the gun. Rains falls to his knees, numb from the tension. Frank rides up. Jesse empties Pinkerton's gun and hands i to him. Pinkerton holds him for a second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (low) Tennessee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesse doesn't understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The railroad has no business in Tennessee. Therefore I have no interest in the state of Tennessee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd just as soon kill you, Jesse James. But chasing you takes up too much of my time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fair enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zee RIDES UP. Jesse SWINGS UP onto her horse, and then th RIDE OFF with Frank. We PULL UP AND AWAY, centering on Pinkerton, Rains, and revealing the smoking, burning wreckage of the train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most of the Gang is mounted. Frank, Cole and Bob are standing there, watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesse and Zee riding up on one horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You get arrested again, I'll kill you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe I had to blow up a train for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are a hell of a woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't swear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They reach the Gang. Jesse SWINGS OFF his horse, gets one of Cole's BEAR HUGS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Missed you, cousin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Missed you too, cousin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesse notices Cole is oddly emotional, but can't quite figure out what's going on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, you gettin' caught, right after leaving us, some people thought --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pff. All we been through, the thought never crossed my mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two clasp hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Things changed when you quit the gang. For example, I'm now the one who says "Let's ride."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not bad at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's tougher than it looks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where'd you get all these riders?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We didn't. Zerelda did. Turns out your wife makes a hell of an outlaw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what's the plan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesse looks at Zerelda and Frank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think my wife and I might go down Tennessee way, buy a farm. (pause) Goodbye, boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Youngers smile sadly, but NOD. As the Younger brother SADDLE UP, Comanche Tom leans down from the saddle and shakes Jesse's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You stay out of trouble, Jesse. Nobody has as much luck as you used up today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesse getting back on his horse with Zee. Frank stands there and watches them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll meet you down there in a few weeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See you soon. Oh, and I appreciate the distraction back there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, they hardly even noticed us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesse and Frank grin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's ride!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesse flips the reins and he and Zee RIDE OFF, the GANG with the Youngers RIDES OFF in the opposite direction. Frank watches them ride away. WE HEAR faintly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tennessee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll explain on the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then it's Frank alone on the hill. WE CIRCLE around behin him, come around, see he's AGED a little, CIRCLE AGAIN an now he's AGED MORE, we come around one more time and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...we COMPLETE THE CIRCLE and see young Frank James is no an older FRANK JAMES. Still lean, a few wrinkles, a littl grey in the hair, dressed in expensive turn-of-the-centur western clothes. A young man who looks remarkably like Jesse, JIMMY JAMES, 16 years old, is waiting patiently. T two are looking down on the town of Liberty, Missouri, wh is now swollen five sizes larger. The Wild West is disappearing under roads and telegraph wire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y'know, Uncle Frank...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, Jimmy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (genially chiding) ...every time you tell that story, you stop there. That's not how it ended. I was five when my dad got shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. But that's how it should have ended. Your Dad and Mom, riding off into a new life, growing old together, happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They start to walk back to the edge of town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allow a man his version of the past. When you get to be my age, you've got enough painful memories, you're allowed to soften a few of the edges up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds like he was a hell of a man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (chuckling) That he was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're making him a hero now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saved a lot of folk from the railroad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he killed a lot of men, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't argue that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what was he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think... he was just a real interestin' fella to have around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank chuckles again at the memories, claps his hand on Jimmy's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, your Ma's probably holding dinner for us. Once saw the woman blow up a train, don't want to tick her off...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy grins and the pair walk down the hill. We stay ON THEIR BACKS as they continue talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uncle Frank?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah Jimmy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much of that story is true?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything but the boring parts.

dialogues.speaker: OVER CREDITS
dialogues.text: SEPIA TONED PHOTOGRAPHS of JESSE and ZEE enjoying their years as farmers, with VISITORS like FRANK, and the YOUNG also included.
